content.statement: aku:math:category-theory:category-definition is a fundamental concept in Formal-Sciences Mathematics Pure-Mathematics Category-Theory that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

explanation.intuition: Understanding aku:math:category-theory:category-definition helps build foundational knowledge. The concept connects to broader principles in the field.
explanation.key_insight: The key aspects of aku:math:category-theory:category-definition include core principles, common applications, and integration with related concepts.
explanation.technical_details: Technical details involve specific mechanisms, measurements, and evidence-based applications of aku:math:category-theory:category-definition.

formal_definition.latex: \text{A category } \mathcal{C} \text{ consists of:} \\ \text{1. Objects: } \text{ob}(\mathcal{C}) \\ \text{2. Morphisms: } \text{hom}_{\mathcal{C}}(A,B) \text{ for each } A,B \in \text{ob}(\mathcal{C}) \\ \text{3. Composition: } \circ : \text{hom}(B,C) \times \text{hom}(A,B) \to \text{hom}(A,C) \\ \text{4. Identity: } \text{id}_A \in \text{hom}(A,A) \text{ for each } A
components: Morphisms: hom_C(A,B) for each pair A,B
Composition: (g: B→C, f: A→B) ↦ g∘f: A→C
Identity: id_A: A→A for each object A

cross_domain_applications.note: This mathematical concept is APPLIED in other domains

applications.context: Category theory provides the theoretical foundation for functional programming, including composition, functors, and monads
Type theory uses categorical semantics, especially cartesian closed categories
